defs.docs: A library for manipulating memory regions

attributes.value: / A library for manipulating memory regions
/ This crate provides several functions for handling memory pages and regions.
/ It is implemented using platform specific APIs. The library exposes both low
/ and high level functionality for manipulating pages.
/ Not all OS specific quirks are abstracted away. For instance; some OSs
/ enforce memory pages to be readable whilst other may prevent pages from
/ *Note: a region is a collection of one or more pages laying consecutively in
/ This crate is [on crates.io](https://crates.io/crates/region) and can be
/ used by adding `region` to your dependencies in your project's `Cargo.toml`.
/ and this to your crate root:
/   // ... you can also temporarily change a region's protection

attributes.value: / The result type used by this library.

defs.docs: The supplied address is null.

defs.name: SystemCall
defs.docs: A system call failed.

defs.name: MachRegion
defs.docs: A macOS kernel call failed

defs.name: Error
defs.value:
pub enum Error {
    NullAddress,
    EmptyRange,
    FreeMemory,
    ProcfsInput,
    SystemCall(io::Error),
    MachRegion(::libc::c_int),
}
defs.docs: A collection of possible errors.

defs.name: lock
defs.value: pub fn lock(*const u8, usize) -> Result<LockGuard>
defs.docs: Locks one or more memory regions to RAM.

attributes.value: / Locks one or more memory regions to RAM.
/ The memory pages within the address range is guaranteed to stay in RAM
/ except for specials cases such as hibernation and memory starvation.
/ - The address may not be null.
/ - The address is rounded down to the closest page boundary.
/ - The size may not be zero.
/ - The size is rounded up to the closest page boundary, relative to the

defs.name: unlock
defs.value: pub unsafe fn unlock(*const u8, usize) -> Result<()>
defs.docs: Unlocks one or more memory regions from RAM.

attributes.value: / Unlocks one or more memory regions from RAM.
/ - The address may not be null.
/ - The address is rounded down to the closest page boundary.
/ - The size may not be zero.
/ - The size is rounded up to the closest page boundary, relative to the
/ This function is unsafe since it cannot be known whether it is called on a
/ locked region or not. In normal uses cases, the `LockGuard` is recommended

defs.name: LockGuard
defs.docs:
An RAII implementation of a "scoped lock". When this structure is dropped
 (falls out of scope), the virtual lock will be unlocked.

attributes.value: / An RAII implementation of a "scoped lock". When this structure is dropped
/ (falls out of scope), the virtual lock will be unlocked.

defs.name: protect
defs.value: pub unsafe fn protect(*const u8, usize, Protection) -> Result<()>
defs.docs: Changes the memory protection of one or more pages.

attributes.value: / Changes the memory protection of one or more pages.
/ The address range may overlap one or more pages, and if so, all pages within
/ the range will be modified. The previous protection flags are not preserved
/ (if reset of protection flags is desired, use `protect_with_handle`).
/ - The address may not be null.
/ - The address is rounded down to the closest page boundary.
/ - The size may not be zero.
/ - The size is rounded up to the closest page boundary, relative to the
/ This is unsafe since it can change read-only properties of constants and/or
/ modify the executable properties of any code segments.
/ let x: extern "C" fn() -> i32 = unsafe {

defs.name: protect_with_handle
defs.value:
pub unsafe fn protect_with_handle(*const u8, usize, Protection)
-> Result<ProtectGuard>
defs.docs: Changes the memory protection of one or more pages temporarily.

attributes.value: / Changes the memory protection of one or more pages temporarily.
/ The address range may overlap one or more pages, and if so, all pages within
/ the range will be modified. The protection flags will be reset when the
/ This function uses `query_range` internally and is therefore less performant
/ than `protect`. Prefer this function only if a memory protection reset is
/ - The address may not be null.
/ - The address is rounded down to the closest page boundary.
/ - The size may not be zero.
/ - The size is rounded up to the closest page boundary, relative to the
/ This is unsafe since it can change read-only properties of constants and/or
/ modify the executable properties of any code segments.

defs.name: ProtectGuard
defs.docs:
An RAII implementation of "scoped protection". When this structure is dropped
 (falls out of scope), the memory region protection will be reset.

attributes.value: / An RAII implementation of "scoped protection". When this structure is dropped
/ (falls out of scope), the memory region protection will be reset.

defs.name: Protection
defs.docs: Memory page protection constants.

defs.name: NONE
defs.docs: No access allowed at all.

defs.name: READ
defs.docs: Read access; writing and/or executing data will panic.

defs.name: WRITE
defs.docs: Write access; this flag alone may not be supported on all OSs.

defs.name: EXECUTE
defs.docs: Execute access; this may not be allowed depending on DEP.

defs.name: READ_EXECUTE
defs.docs: Read and execute shorthand.

defs.name: READ_WRITE
defs.docs: Read and write shorthand.

defs.name: READ_WRITE_EXECUTE
defs.docs: Read, write and execute shorthand.

defs.name: WRITE_EXECUTE
defs.docs: Write and execute shorthand.

defs.name: None
defs.docs: No access allowed at all.

defs.name: Read
defs.docs: Read access; writing and/or executing data will panic.

defs.name: Write
defs.docs: Write access; this flag alone may not be supported on all OSs.

defs.name: Execute
defs.docs: Execute access; this may not be allowed depending on DEP.

defs.name: ReadExecute
defs.docs: Read and execute shorthand.

defs.name: ReadWrite
defs.docs: Read and write shorthand.

defs.name: ReadWriteExecute
defs.docs: Read, write and execute shorthand.

defs.name: WriteExecute
defs.docs: Write and execute shorthand.

defs.name: query
defs.docs: Queries the OS with an address, returning the region it resides within.

attributes.value: / Queries the OS with an address, returning the region it resides within.
/ The implementation uses `VirtualQuery` on Windows, `mach_vm_region` on macOS,
/ `kinfo_getvmmap` on FreeBSD, and parses `proc/[pid]/maps` on Linux.
/ - The enclosing region can be of multiple page sizes.
/ - The address is rounded down to the closest page boundary.
/ - The address may not be null.

defs.name: query_range
defs.value: pub fn query_range(*const u8, usize) -> Result<Vec<Region>>
defs.docs: Queries the OS with a range, returning the regions it contains.

attributes.value: / Queries the OS with a range, returning the regions it contains.
/ A 2-byte range straddling a page boundary will return both pages (or one
/ region, if the pages have the same properties). The implementation uses
/ - The address is rounded down to the closest page boundary.
/ - The address may not be null.
/ - The size may not be zero.
